head.title: Mining the Show House, Where the Ideas Are Worth The Price of the Ticket

series.series.name: CURRENTS: KIPS BAY SHOPPER -- INTERIOR DESIGN

hedline.hl1: Mining the Show House, Where the Ideas Are Worth The Price of the Ticket

block.p: SURE, decorators are selling luxury,'' the designer Mario Buatta said. ''But for most visitors, a show house is like a reference library of terrific ideas.'' His distinctive style can be seen in an oval sitting room at the Kips Bay Decorator Show House (at 1 East 94th Street through May 21). In fact, visiting a show house is like visiting a think tank for design professionals like Charles Spada, a Boston decorator whose off-white study is also featured at Kips Bay. ''People should go to a show house to be inspired and to take ideas away with them,'' Mr. Spada said. So visit with pencil and paper in hand (and $20 for the price of a ticket) or try any of these 10 ideas -- and some less expensive sources -- from the 28th Kips Bay Show House.

1. The decorating firm of Anderson Papachristidis Raeymaekers used shutter doors to camouflage an awkwardly positioned corner window and give the illusion of a balcony door. Similar unpainted shutter doors are $49 to $69 a pair at the Home Depot (www .homedepot.com or (800) 430-3376 for locations).

Similar unpainted shutter doors are $49 to $69 a pair at the Home Depot (www .homedepot.com or (800) 430-3376 for locations).

2. Richard L. Ridge and Roderick R. Denault boldly upholstered four identical club chairs from Brun schwig & Fils, each in a different solid-color Brun schwig fabric ($46.50 to $148.50 a yard). Inexpensive cotton canvas, for a similar effect, is available in eight colors ($20 a yard, 64 inches wide) at Jensen Lewis, 89 Seventh Avenue (16th Street).

3. Why take up floor space with a piece of uninteresting, temporary furniture like a baby-changing table when a carpenter can build one of plywood and hinge it to the wall? The one in Penny Drue Baird's baby room (easily removed when a child is older) folds up and stays put with a decorative bow.

4. The white lacquered Parsons table used by Charles Spada in his study has convenient extensions on each end. ''This table is reminiscent of 18th-century writing tables that had extensions as can dlestands,'' he said. ''I like to customize a classic to suit individual needs.'' A similar but unpainted birch Parsons table, 5 feet by 2 feet by 30 inches high, is $349 with 16-inch extensions at Gothic Cabinet Craft, 360 Avenue of the Americas (Washington Place).

5. A walk-in closet by Stingray Hornsby looks luxurious and neat with ceiling-to-floor wood Venetian blinds that cover the clutter. Blinds like these by Hunter Douglas can be ordered at good prices from Smith & Noble, (800) 560-0027 or www .smithandnoble.com.

6. Ani Antreasyan ''carpeted'' a roof deck with willow garden fencing from Smith & Hawken that is $69 for a roll 4 feet wide by 9 feet long, or $49 for a roll 3 by 9 feet; (800) 776-3336 or www.smithandhawken.com for store locations and orders.
7. Randall A. Ridless hung brass curtain rods to create movable displays of artwork. The hardware, in many sizes and finishes, is available at Gracious Home, 1220 Third Avenue (71st Street).

8. Tonin MacCallum accessorized a sofa with embroidered Indian throw pillows, $75 each, and custom-made pillows of brightly colored silk, $15 a yard, both from Little India Emporium, 128 East 28th Street. The crystal fringe is $9 to $15 a yard at the M&J Trimming Company, 1008 Avenue of the Americas (38th Street).

9. Roderick N. Shade also embellished throw pillows, using fringe ($35.50 to $108 a yard) and fabric ($46.50 to $139 a yard) from F. Schumacher & Company. African-style heavy cotton fabric, $12 to $15 a yard, and fringe ($3 to $20 a yard) are available from Joe's Fabric and Trimmings, 110 Orchard Street (Delancey Street).

10. David Barrett's traditional silk draperies are made much like a shower curtain, with grommets that hang simply on large silver-leafed nails. Penny pinchers can just go ahead and paint their own nails.
